title: Erdős Problem #457: Small Prime Divisors of Consecutive Products
description: Is there ε > 0 such that infinitely many n have all primes p ≤ (2+ε)log(n) dividing the product of log(n) consecutive integers starting at n+1? Equivalently, q(n,log n) ≥ (2+ε)log(n) i.o. OPEN.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős Problem #457, posed by Erdős and Pomerance [Er79d], [ErGr80], asks about small prime divisors of consecutive products. The function q(n,k) = smallest prime not dividing the product of k consecutive integers after n provides an equivalent formulation. A construction shows q(n, log n) >= (2+o(1))log(n). Related to Problem #663.
overview.problemStatement: Is there ε > 0 such that for infinitely many n, all primes p <= (2+ε)log(n) divide the product of the first floor(log n) integers after n? OPEN.
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines consecutiveProduct and smallestNonDividingPrime (q(n,k)). The main conjecture uses Set.Infinite. The equivalent q(n,k) formulation and upper bound sub-question are stated separately.
keyInsights: The product of log(n) consecutive integers after n is divisible by many small primes
q(n,k) = smallest prime not dividing the consecutive product captures the problem
Open sub-question: q(n, log n) < (1-ε)(log n)² for all large n
Connected to the distribution of primes in short intervals

sections.title: Part I: Consecutive Products
sections.summary: Defines consecutiveProduct(n, k) = product of (n+i) for i in [1, k].

sections.title: Part II: The Smallest Non-Dividing Prime
sections.summary: Defines smallestNonDividingPrime(n, k) = q(n, k) via Nat.find. 1 sorry.

sections.title: Part III: The Main Conjecture
sections.summary: Defines ErdosConjecture457: exists ε > 0 with infinitely many n where all small primes divide. Axiom erdos_457.

sections.title: Part IV: Equivalent Formulation via q(n, k)
sections.summary: Defines ErdosConjecture457_q: q(n, log n) >= (2+ε)log(n) infinitely often. Axiom erdos_457_q.

sections.title: Part V: Known Construction and Upper Bound Question
sections.summary: Axiom construction_lower: q >= (2+o(1))log(n) achievable. Defines UpperBoundConjecture. Axiom erdos_457_upper.

sections.title: Part VI: Summary
sections.summary: Proved: erdos_457_statement (simp), erdos_457_status (trivial). All formulations OPEN.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #457 asks whether small primes frequently divide consecutive products of length log(n). The equivalent q(n,k) formulation and upper bound sub-question are also open.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would clarify the divisibility structure of short consecutive products and connect to smooth number theory.
openQuestions: Is q(n, log n) >= (2+ε)log(n) infinitely often for some ε > 0?
Is q(n, log n) < (1-ε)(log n)² for all large n?
What is the true growth rate of q(n, log n)?
How does this connect to Problem #663?
